I would get rid of this but there are times when I get nostalgic and like remembering how I stupid I used to be. Funny to think how much has changed so I last posted on this lj.

But I guess the main thing is that I don't really care to talk about myself anymore. I'm just not about that, not as much as I used to be. I used to have a lot to say about things but I generally keep it all to myself. I still write about film and what not but it's impersonal to me. I mean, films mean a lot to me but writing about them is an impersonal activity.

I try to channel my feelings into what I write in other areas like screenplays or short stories that I have come up with over the years. But lately, that well has been kind of try. It's moreso about me getting the motivation to write than anything else. I know the ideas are there, I just can't seem to get myself to go ahead with them.

I miss simpler times but I wouldn't trade where I am at now, obviously. I just feel a little too complacent sometimes. I'm satisfied with where I am at right now, I love my wife, and I have a lot of hope for the future. Part of that includes getting my act together and pursuing filmmaking projects that I can ill-afford to put aside much longer. The good news is that I have a couple of film shoots that I'll be a part of this upcoming month and I plan to have a lot more going on for me in the near future. Main thing is, I just don't even plan on giving up on these dreams anytime soon. They're not dreams anymore, you know? I'm a filmmaker and that's that. I wish I could do something more substantial and consistent to earn a paycheck but I have a feeling that I will get everything I want if I just keep doing what I'm doing now. If I just keep plugging away, everything will be fine. Now's the time to do it before I start having kids and what not.

Anyway, I wrote way more than I intended. Nobody will read this.

As a man who likes to put things into perspective, I come into the win that Penn State had against Ohio State with excitement and caution.  Not that I don't believe PSU will be able to win out, I think that should be able to happen.  It has to happen.  This team is too disciplined to let a game against Iowa, Indiana, or Michigan State get out of hand.  Besides, when you matchup our team against theirs, it seemed implausible for any of those team to have a clear advantage against us.  That being said, we do have to get sexy on offense again, and fast.  We did well in the 2nd half of the Michigan game, but we have to make sure we're able to come out firing like we did in the Wisconsin and Illinois games.  We have to solidify our status as a well-balanced offensive team with great running backs, receivers, and a poised quarterback that has a great arm and the mobility to get out of pressure situations. 

    So it is.  Penn State has a realistic chance to go 12-0 in the regular season right now and once again, like a few other undefeated teams that Joe Pa has coached... this team will face the same questions no matter what.  Especially now.  They beat Ohio State 13-6.  So, I'm sure SEC or Big 12 fans are asking, "So what?"  What's so great about PSU?  Nevermind beating Michigan 46-17, Wisconsin 48-7, Illinois 38-24... that doesn't matter.  Those teams are garbage anyway.  It seems that PSU can't just beat the teams they play in the Big Ten.  They have to REALLY beat them.  I understand that clearly.  Yet, that's so lame, isn't it?  How does USC get anymore respect than PSU does when they lost to an Oregon State team that got manhandled earlier in the year by Penn State?  USC beat a Beanie Wells-less Ohio State team lead by Todd Boeckman in LA.  Penn State beat a Ohio State team that was lead by "Freshmen phenom" Terrelle Pryor and Beanie Wells.  It was a hard fought defensive team, yet nobody wants to give Penn State's defense any credit (except the ones who actually know college football).  

    The bottom line is that Penn State fans will now have to endure criticism for the next 2 1/2 months.  2 1/2 months!  Are you looking forward to it?  I know I am!  With every win:  "Oh so what?  They beat Iowa!  Big deal!"  "Michigan State?  Who gives a shit?!"  Yup.  Then, when Penn State reaches the National Title game against either Alabama or Texas... leading up to that game will be Texas and Alabama fans who are absolutely sure that PSU will get crushed by their "explosive offensives."  Could that happen?  Sure.  And that's the thing.  Penn State can't just win out in the regular season.  They HAVE to win in the national championship game.  They have to.  If they don't, the Big Ten will be in terrible, terrible shape.  Nobody will have any respect for the Big Ten.  Pollsters won't want to let a Big Ten team into the national championship again because they fear another blowout.  Penn State HAS to win every game they play this season.  That's a lot of pressure.    And this is assuming that Alabama or Texas will have at least one loss.  And what if Texas Tech wins out?  I mean, Penn State has to withstand a lot in order to get to the BCS championship game.  If both Alabama and Texas win out, then we can look forward to another undefeated PSU team that doesn't get awarded at least a share of the national championship game.  That'll be the fourth time that has happened to Joe Paterno!  1968, 1969, 1973, 1994, 2008... wait... that's FIVE TIMES!  Good God.  C'mon, college football Gods.  For the sake of college football, PSU has to win the national championship this year, or it'll never be the same.

In fact, it is probably my favorite year ever in the NFL.  The ironic part is that the Steelers didn't even make the playoffs that year!  But hey, I can accept that because what lead to them missing out on the playoffs was a meltdown by the Steelers of which I've never seen.  That's not entirely their fault though.  Essentially losing the Thanksgiving game against the Lions because of a botched coin flip could knock the wind out of any team.  I remember how frustrated, confused, and angry I was about it and when I saw the Steelers go from 7-4 to 7-9, I wasn't even upset.  I knew it wasn't entirely their fault.  I felt their pain, so to speak.  I think that was the first year I remember the Steelers not making the playoffs, I grew up watching the Steelers since Bill Cowher became coach.  To me, Bill Cowher was synonymous with the Steelers so to see him go after the 2006 season was forcing me to accept change.  It's ok though, I love Mike Tomlin.

But that's beside the point.

The first question you're going to ask me is, what's so bad about the NFL 1999-present?  Well, nothing... not really.  I mean, the Steelers won the Super Bowl in 2005, what's not to love about that?  What a perfect way for Jerome Bettis to retire, right?  The Steelers run in the latter part of the 2005 season was definitely fun to watch, but the whole season just wasn't that exciting to me.

Let's go back to 1998 though.  Look at who was still playing that year:

John Elway
Dan Marino
Steve Young
Randall Cunningham
Warren Moon
Troy Aikman

I say "still" because all of these quarterbacks were in their twilight of their legendary careers.  5/6 are already in the Hall of Fame, one of them will make it in eventually.  And, it's not as if these guys were playing like old-timers.  John Elway lead the Broncos to a Super Bowl victory.  Dan Marino had a solid season and lead the Dolphins to the playoffs.  Steve Young had one of his best years as a quarterback, statistically:  36 tds, 12 ints, 4,170 passing yards, 101.1 passer rating... did I mention all three of these quarterbacks were at least 37 years old?  Don't forget Warren Moon, who didn't have such a hot season, but he still played pretty decent for being 42 years old... Jesus Christ.  Troy Aikman had a great season too, but little did we know that this would be his last great season before he retired two seasons later at age 34.  But the best story out of these six quarterbacks was Randall Cunningham.  Cunningham had a career that was filled with amazing seasons and seasons where he was plagued by injury.  Well, he came back this year on a friggin' mission.  He had a bad injury the year before and came back putting up 34 touchdown passes and only 10 interceptions, and 3,704 passing yards.  He was 35 years old, lead the Vikings to a 15-1 season, many people consider this one of the greatest teams to never win a Super Bowl.  Ok, I consider them that.  More on them later.

We had more great stories with either up-and-coming quarterbacks and quarterbacks with a great comeback season.  This includes:

Brett Favre
Vinny Testaverde
Doug Flutie
Drew Bledsoe
Peyton Manning
Jake Plummer
Trent Green
Mark Brunell
Steve McNair
Chris Chandler
Rich Gannon

If you're an NFL fan, you are bound to remember all of these guys.  Some of these guys went on to have legendary careers, some of them went on to have solid careers, some... never could follow up their magical 1998 season.

First, there's Brett Favre.  He didn't have one of his best years this year, but he still threw for 4,212 yards and 31 td passes.  It was the 5th year in a row that he threw for more than 30 touchdown passes.  That is just sick and I don't think any quarterback will ever match that.  Then, you have Vinny Testaverde!  Come on, how great of a story is that?  It's not some ridiculous "where the hell did this guy come from?" type of story either (like Kurt Warner in '99 or Tom Brady in '01)... this guy sucked in the NFL for over 10 seasons.  Sure, he did go to the pro bowl in 1996 as a Raven... but who remembers that?  No, 1998 was his true breakout year.  Interceptions and Testaverde used to go together like peanut butter and jelly.  Well, guess what bitches?  This year, Vinny threw for 29 touchdown passes and 7 interceptions. He was awesome!  According to pro-football-reference.com, his record with the Jets that season was 12-1.  Vinny's overall QB record is 90-123-1... you see what I'm getting at?  Who knows what was in his water this year, but he lead to Jets to a 12-4 record and all the way to the conference championship.  

You know, that 12-1 record sounds pretty amazing, who can top that?  Oh, I don't know, maybe Chris Chandler?  He had a 13-1 record when he lead the 14-2 Falcons to the Super Bowl which we'll get to later. Chandler was pretty much a journeyman quarterback before he joined the Falcons in 1997 and he just exploded in 1998.  Let's wrap this up quickly... Doug Flutie was a Heisman winner and later a CFL star, but he was considered too short to be an NFL QB.  Well, he lead the Bills to a 10-6 record in 1998 and made the pro bowl.  Did I mention he was 36 years old?  I also wanna talk about Jake Plummer.  Now when you look at his stats, they aren't spectacular, but he was playing for the CARDINALS.  In his second season, he lead the Cardinals to their first playoff appearance since 1982 (which was a strike year so it doesn't really count so, 1975).  He lead them to their first playoff victory since 1947!  That is pretty amazing folks.

Of course, we can talk about Peyton Manning breaking all kinds of rookie records in 1998, Drew Bledsoe leading the Pats to another playoff appearance, Trent Green and Rich Gannon finally showed the NFL that they deserve to be starters in the league... there are so many stories when it comes to quarterbacks, you could write a book about it.

Now let's look at the rest of the players who played in 1998:

Running backs -
Barry Sanders
Terrell Davis
Curtis Martin
Jerome Bettis
Marshall Faulk
Emmitt Smith
Eddie George
Jamal Anderson
Robert Smith
Ricky Watters

You also had Warrick Dunn, Priest Holmes, Corey Dillon, and Fred Taylor who later went on to have solid careers in the NFL.

Barry Sanders was in his last season, Terrell Davis and Jamal Anderson had such great seasons that they couldn't top.
Jerome Bettis, Curtis Martin, Marshall Faulk, and Eddie George were all in their prime.  Robert Smith helped balance out the Vikings amazing offense.  I feel you can't talk about the 1998 Vikings without talking about him.  Emmitt Smith was still going strong and Ricky Watters had one last good season.

Let's just go through other great players:
Jerry Rice, Tim Brown, Rod Smith, Keyshawn Johnson, Cris Carter, Jimmy Smith, Michael Irvin, Randy Moss, Eric Moulds, Terrell Owens, Herman Moore, Shannon Sharpe, Antonio Freeman, Larry Allen, Tony Boselli, Jonathan Ogden, Willie Roaf, Dermotti Dawson, Michael Strahan, Will Shields, Reggie White, Warren Sapp, John Randle, Bruce Smith, Mo Lewis, Ray Lewis, Bill Romanowski, Derrick Brooks, Chad Brown, Junior Seau, Ty Law, Charles Woodson, Deion Sanders, Rodney Harrison, Rod Woodson, Darren Woodson, LeRoy Butler

Did I mention that kicker Gary Anderson had a perfect year?  He missed no field goals or extra points and he kicked 35 field goals and 59 extra points.

I know there are great players playing today, but just look at the combination of legendary players with young up-and-coming players that were soon to become great.  I mean, you had Terrell Owens and Jerry Rice on the same team.  You had Cris Carter and Randy Moss on the same team. 

You can't just say 1998 was a great year because of the players, obviously.  I know that there are great players playing every year.  I just wanted to point out the combination of all of them in the same year.  And, yeah, to me, Barry Sanders and John Elway retiring this year... two of the greatest players to play in their position... that signaled a new era. 

I'm going to finish this by going over the 1998 from a team standpoint.

First we have to start off with the Super Bowl champs, the Denver Broncos.  I think they were the last team, so far, to dominate in both offense and defense in a multiple year period while winning the Super Bowl.  The '03-'04 Patriots had great defenses and of course... Tom Brady.  But they didn't put up the kind of points that the Broncos did.  I'm not denying that those Patriots teams were great teams, but I just think the '97-'98 Broncos had a better two year period regardless of the fact that the Patriots went 28-4 and Denver went 27-5.  I'm talking from a purely statistical standpoint.  Of course, what's even more fitting is that it was Elway's last two seasons as a Bronco.  You know, we look at how Bettis and Strahan ended their careers with their teams while winning the Super Bowl and we think that those are great stories.  They are.  But, to have your team go 27-5, win two Super Bowls, and then retire?  That's just insane.  And you know, the Broncos had to beat the Jets and the Falcons to win the Super Bowl, both teams were on magical runs and we'll start with the Jets.

Simply saying that the Jets went 12-4 is amazing, but the fact that they started off at 0-2 (and later, 2-3) to go on to 12-4, that's even more amazing.  THEN, to say that Vinny Testaverde was the quarterback that lead them there... ok, what the hell?  This is truly an awesome story right here.  Bill Parcells improved the team noticeably the year before from 1-15 to 7-9.  I'm sure Jets fans were just happy to see their team become competitive again.  But to go 12-4 is just unbelievable.  It wasn't a fluke either.  This Jets team was ranked 4th in offense and 7th in defense.  They had 5 pro-bowlers.  Curtis Martin and Keyshawn Johnson had breakout years.  They were 5th in scoring and 2nd in giving up points.  The fact that the Broncos were able to beat this team so handily is very impressive.  And, of course, this season makes you wonder what could've happened in 1999 if Vinny Testaverde didn't get hurt in week 1.

The Atlanta Falcons were so fun to watch in 1998.  While the Broncos and the Jets were going on their own runs, the Falcons decided to become good also.  They went 14-2 and was lead by Chris Chandler who had a breakout year and Jamal Anderson... nobody could stop him that year. 

Did I mention that the Vikings went 15-1?  They had Cunningham, Robert Smith, Cris Carter, and Randy Moss?  That they held the record for most points scored in a season until the Patriots broke that in 2007?  Yeah well guess what?  The Falcons beat them in the Conference Championship.  That's how fucking crazy this season was!  The Minnesota Vikings looked unstoppable throughout the season until the Falcons... stopped them.  And then, to top all that, the Broncos (remember them?) beat the Falcons in the Super Bowl!  In my honest opinion, I think that in any other year, the Vikings and the Falcons could win the Super Bowl with their teams easily.  The fact that all three of these teams were playing in the same year is just incredible.

I also want to point out the fact that this was the last year that the Packers and 49ers faced in each other in the playoffs with Steve Young, Brett Favre, Mike Holmgren, Steve Mariucci, Jerry Rice, Terrell Owens, Reggie White... all inside the same stadium.  And what followed was one of the greatest playoff games of all time.  The 49ers had a great team that year, they were having a great team every year since the '80s at this point.  Even though they would later make the playoffs with Jeff Garcia, it wasn't the same as it was when Joe Montana/Steve Young were the quarterbacks and Jerry Rice was the main receiver.  That was something you expected to happen every year.  You expected either the Packers, Cowboys, or 49ers to face each other at some point the playoffs during the '90s.  Eventually all three of them won the Super Bowl in the '90s.  This was the last year where the 49ers and the Cowboys still had most of the same players that made those teams so memorable.  The Cowboys went 10-6 and lost to the Cardinals in the playoffs.  This would signal the end of the Cowboys' era officially.  It would take almost a decade until they were able to gather enough talent to be considered serious Super Bowl contenders.

The Cardinals story is special because it's not like they went from a 4-12 season to a 13-3 season like the Rams did in '98-'99.  Now, this was the same Cardinals team as always.  They weren't that good in 1998... if you look at them on paper.  But they found a way to win 9 games that year lead by 2nd year quarterback Jake Plummer.  They somehow managed to pull it off and to beat the Cowboys, of all teams, in the playoffs is just... special.

In summation, like I said before, there are a lot of great moments that happened since the 1998-99 season.  The Rams-Titans super bowl is still probably the greatest super bowl I've ever seen.  But think about it what the NFL was like in the 90s.  Like I said, every year, the Cowboys, Niners, and Packers made the playoffs, it seemed.  1998 was the last year that this happened with all the same familiar faces that you saw every year.  There's a lot of parity in the NFL now.  A team that makes the Super Bowl this year, may not make it the next year.  Sure, that makes things exciting because you don't know who to expect in the playoffs in any year.  The fact that the Patriots and Colts are able to make the playoffs every year in this era is just astounding considering the amount of parity that happens.  1998 was the beginning of that parity happening, if you look at it.  I mean, the Falcons?  The Vikings?  The Vikings had decent enough teams in the '90s, but they were never that good.  1998 was the year it all came together for them.  Cardinals making the playoffs?  Jets going 12-4?  Yeah, parity definitely still existed in the 1998.  But, it co-existed with the great dynasties that were the Packers, Cowboys, Broncos, and Niners.  After this year, those dynasties broke down.  Now we only really have the Colts and Patriots every year.  The NFC is only finally starting to come together.  The AFC has a lot of good teams, but only two great teams every year.  It seems like any year a supposed other "great" team comes along, another team winds up surprising them.  The Giants beating the 18-0 Patriots?  Peyton Manning and the Colts finally won the Super Bowl in 2006, but they should've won it in 2005.  I'm glad the Steelers beat the Colts that year to win the Super Bowl, but the Colts in 2005 had that feel of a historic-type team.  The 2006 Chargers also had that feeling and they blew it too.  The 2007 Patriots seemed to resemble the 1994 49ers in that they stocked up on talent and wound up dominating.  But the fact that they lost in the Super Bowl just ruins the whole season; the whole historical factor of their team is just gone.  

The past three years in the NFL seemed to signify that all you need to do is have a great late season run and you can win the Super Bowl.  There's no sense of total domination throughout the season, there's no sense of truly great teams (except for the Colts and Patriots, once again) playing against each other annually and it means something.  I will say this, as a sign of optimism, I think the NFL is on the verge of having stronger teams overall.  We're starting to see more consistency at the quarterback position with multiple teams.  Over the years, teams like the Broncos, Chargers, Steelers, Cowboys, Packers, and Giants should start to show some consistency every year with their young quarterbacks as all are showing signs of greatness.  To me, it's more fun to watch great football teams play each other every year, then to have a surprise team come out of nowhere and make a run to the Super Bowl.  Or, at least, win the damn Super Bowl if you're actually that good.

It would be unreasonably pessimistic of me to call my life so far a bunch of missed opportunities.  After all, where I am right now isn't that bad of a situation.  Who knows where I'd be if I had been more of an active participant in my life, rather than a passive observer.  Sure it may seem like that at some point I took charge of my life and steered in a good direction.  I'm not denying that I am partly responsible.  But part of me feels that I was meant to end up where I am now anyway and I only did everything in my power not to be a total failure.  Well, congrats to that, right?  I mean, one should take pride in not making stupid decisions with their life, but sometimes I feel like there were decisions I could've made in the past that I didn't make, but I should've made.

Most of these cases are with women, too.  Is that really a surprise though?  You know I've come to the opinion that it really isn't that hard to pursue a woman or get one to like you.  It really isn't, and I've probably had my chances with women that I can name off the top of my head.  The problem is that it seems all those chances are way gone and if I were to even begin to try to pursue any of those women, I'd be thought of as a stalker.  Don't worry, wasn't thinking about going down that road.

But, looking back, there always seemed to be many different paths to relationships for me, and I kept going down the wrong one, or missing them completely.  One wonders if this will be a neverending thing for me.  I can't honestly go that much longer into my life without finding a woman that really means something to me, can I?  The problem is that there probably have been opportunities for this to happen before but I just didn't let myself make it happen.  Even now I feel this urge not to do anything when put in that situation.  And why?  What's the worst that can happen?  It makes no sense to be like that.  I realize this and yet I keep falling down that unfortunate path.  As I've mentioned before, when I do get involved in a relationship, it feels completely unnatural and something that I want to get out of.  I feel a large part of the reason for that is because it is something that I didn't go after.  What I need - I need to successfully go after someone who I feel has some interest in me.  I feel the satisfaction of getting to that point is something that I've been looking for all this time.  What's it gonna take for me to make a good move?  I'm not really sure, but I do know that as time goes on, I have less and less to lose when it comes to taking a chance.  And more to lose when it comes to not taking a chance.  So, why can't I fucking do it?

I have never understood the willingness to be dumb.  The one thing I learned in high school was that popular/cool kids can be in smart classes.  But, there is still this idea that being dumb is cool.  This has continued on through the internet where people have stopped learning how to type properly.  They use shorthand after shorthand and butcher the English language in the process.  It's really sad that this is what we have become.  You know, it's not very hard to type like this.  Now I don't mean to place myself above others of my age, in general, as I'm sure there are plenty out there like me who actually have a vocabulary that they can use extensively.  My problem is that there seems to be this push towards typing with shorthand and, to me, it would seem that it takes more time to remember what the shorthands are for longer words anyway.  So why not just type normally?  There's nothing cool about coming off like a retard.  I'm not asking people to type like geniuses; just type.  This really isn't hard.

I had somewhat understood why bullies picked on smart kids.  I think the main reason is that "nerds" or "geeks" really do it to themselves.  I managed to go throughout elementary, intermediate, and high school without getting my ass kicked, so why do other people have problems?  I'm not "cool" or anything but I managed to get by.  And you know, there wasn't really a "bully" that existed.  There wasn't anybody I knew who seemed to deliberately try to make a geek have a bad day.  It seemed to me that the kids that were bullied during those school years acted so dumb and had no sense of humor.  I managed to go through school with a sense of humor.  I was able to make fun of myself and laughed when people made fun of me.  The only time I took things seriously was when we were playing sports.  Yes, I cried when I lost a kickball game, but what's wrong with that?  Sports are serious shit, man.

But, you know what it is?  I felt so inferior when it came to almost all sports.  I don't know why I was so bad, maybe I just didn't have the right attitude.  I was just terrible at almost every sport out there, but I managed to get by.  At the same time, it is undeniable that I'd get upset whenever we lost a game in whatever sport that was being played because I'd always feel that it was directly my fault.  Sometimes it was.  There was just this overall feeling that'd go through me and it felt like I personally failed everytime I lost a game.  It didn't matter to me that the game meant nothing in general.  I wanted to prove that I was good at something.

I never really got picked on about that though.  I mean, I did.  However, it wasn't something that people really got on me for.  I did get picked on somewhat for sucking at a lot of sports, but that only lasts until the end of whatever game that's being played.  As I've grown up, I've learned to deal with losses more gracefully.  I've also grown my sense of humor.  I'd say high school was the best version of me because my main goal was just to make people laugh and be completely nonsensical at times.  I also made sure that I was doing it in a smart way.  I'd never call what I did back then "dumb humor" because I always had a point to whatever joke I was making.  There was always some ironic twist going on.  I wasn't always deliberately trying to do that.  As junior and senior year came along, it was just something that I did naturally.  I'm just glad most people caught along to it.

Anyway, so, I guess what I'm saying is that people should just lighten the hell up.  You can avoid many ass beatings that way.

Maybe you are wondering what I have done in the past few years or months or however long it's been since you've heard from me last.  I don't know who reads this or if anybody reads this, but I like to pretend in my head that this is the most famous blog in all of livejournal.  

What Myspace and facebook are good for is the fact that I can look to see how many failures/screwups there were who graduated at the same time and place I did.  Is it a bit mean to think of it in that manner?  I suppose.  There are times when it's just weird, knowing that you used to see these people around everyday of your school life and now they are out doing whatever it is they're doing.  The people on facebook are generally in college and are doing well for themselves, the people on myspace (who aren't on facebook) are kind of in the opposite situation.  But, maybe, I have the wrong perspective.  I look and see a few who have had kids and a family; I think to myself "wow, already?"  But am I supposed to laugh and feel sorry for them?  I guess not.  I guess that you can be happy by already having a kid and to be married... of course, if it's a single mother than the connotations surrounding that are much bleaker.  But, nonetheless, I am actually envious of those people in a way.  I look at my own life and find myself lacking that certain feeling that everyone else has in their life.  I mean, I've actually gone through a relationship this past winter/spring, but it is nothing worth talking about.  Trust me.  The bottom line is that I find myself right back where I started:  single.  I've had this lj for over four years and I've always lamented and complained about the same thing:  the fact that I'm single.  

I always wind up blaming myself and all that usual crybaby nonsense.  But, it's not that I'm depressed or upset about it because I am doing pretty well for myself otherwise.  I'm a year away from being a Penn State graduate.  Tomorrow I'm going to NYC to interview for an internship and if I get it that means I'll be interning for a production company in NYC.  How sweet is that?  I like it.

And yet, I still wonder what my life would be like if I didn't go to college, found someone locally, married them, had a kid, lived my life that way.  My personal philosophy is to go out there, experience the broad spectrum of life, then settle down and have kids.  But, people choose to just settle down and have kids.  I suppose it wouldn't be such a bad thing to have that.  But of course, then you'd have a low-paying job and may be struggling to pay bills.  I've seen how many parents manage and I don't think I'd want to be in that position exactly.

No, this is what I have to do.  I have to be a member of my family who succeeds and I can't hope for the possibility of walking into a successful situation at age 40.  I can't do that.  This is what needs to be done.  This is the path I have to go down.  I'm gonna do it too.  I am determined to do it.

So this is for anybody who stumbled upon my livejournal and wondered, "What has Ken been doing lately?"  Well, here's a surprise for you, I am doing pretty damn well for myself.  I don't know what fellow classmates expected from me back in high school or intermediate school, but here I am.  Take it as you will.

I'm undecided as to where I should blog these days, but I've decided to do a little stint back on livejournal just for awhile, anyway.  I wanted to be cool and hip by switching off to the cutting edge that is blogspot.com, but I can't help but dig the nostalgic aura that surrounds lj.  

A part of me kind of misses Toms River, NJ.  Don't get me wrong, I'm here.  I've been back in town for over a week now, but I hardly talk to anyone.  I hardly talk to any of my "friends" in Toms River.  I put friends in quotations because I'm undecided as to whether or not the people I talked to here were really my friends or not.  Hell, I'm still undecided as to whether or not the people I talk to in State College are my friends.

I seem to have a hard time opening up to people.  I have no problem with hanging out and partying, but I do not seem to do much of that anymore as well.  It feels like whenever I do becomes friends with someone, it usually lasts until they get sick of me.  I don't seem to make a lasting impression on people.  The people I used to talk to in Toms River don't want to give me the time of the day nowadays.  At least, not really.  Maybe that's my fault.  I just wish I knew where I could fix that.  I don't think of myself as a bad person, and it seems dumb people can hang onto friends longer than me.  So, I'm really kind of confused about it all.  I think of myself as a pretty normal, regular guy.  But, I don't know, something must've happened to me along the way that has turned me into a bit of a loner. How do you break the news to someone that you know what they've done and you wish to never see them again?

Especially if that someone is supposed to be a member of your own family?

Answer me that.

Every other blog I've made on here is just bullshit. You know it, I know it, anyone in the world who reads it knows that. It means nothing. It's oh so insignificant. I realize now that I've got a lot that I should appreciate and I shouldn't bitch and moan just because one slight thing doesn't go my way.

But, friends, what I'm about to talk about now is not bullshit. This is pure. This is something I won't regret reading in twenty years. It's something that I just can't bottle up for the rest of my life or keep away from other people. I don't want people to think that I think I have it worse than anyone else. There are people all over the world who has life one hundred times worse than me and I guess I should have no reason to complain about anything right?

This is not me complaining or moaning. This is me mourning and grieving. This is regret, pain, loss, and confusion. This is me calling out to everyone who reads to this and understands what I'm saying. Now I've talked to a few people before and they made feel better. They're not around all the time. My family is around more, but they're going through this worse than I am. That doesn't mean I don't feel as bad as them, but they're going through the same things I am and I just can't get a good perspective on things when I talk to them. I tried. But they're all thinking the same things I am, I'm sure. They're all wondering, or have wondered the things that I've wondered. And what I'm 100% positive with is that I'm sure they all have the same pain I do. That's what it is. It's pain. I feel a pain in my stomach and my heart pounds in my chest. I'm trying to just forget about it and think of something else, but it's impossible when I feel the pain that I do. I know that I can't just let it sit there so what can I do? How can I cope through my grandfather's death? How am I gonna feel when my own mother dies? Will I feel worse? Should I not feel so bad? I know I'm supposed to remember all the good times, but when I do I just feel like crying. It's gone. The memories will be there, but I'll never be able to make more memories with him. It'll all end the same way. We lost our bond at the end. We just weren't as close as I wish we were before he died. I haven't had a heartfelt talk with him in years. Even then, he was drunk. It's just I feel bad. And I can't help it. I just do. It won't let go no matter how hard I try to make it go away. What am I gonna do? I never felt this pain before. I never felt this grief before. Other people have dealt with this a countless number of times before, but I could never understand what they were going through because I never went through it. Now I'm going through it for the very first time and no matter how many people tell me that what I'm feeling is normal, my heart and stomach just don't receive that message. It's those things that make me feel this way. I just hate this feeling and I want it to go away, but I know I'll have to live with it. I'll be fine in the head. I think I'm strong enough mentally. I haven't broken down or cried, I just feel sad. But it's a prolonged sadness. It just doesn't go away no matter what. I don't know what to do. I don't know if I'm supposed to get help. It's normal to feel this way, right? Am I fine? I'm sorry if you're reading this and rolling your eyes, but I just don't know how to react. I figured this is the best way to let it out. Just tell everyone and let them come up with their own opinion. You don't have to say anything to me, but just read this. Take it in and reflect. Did you feel this way when someone close to you died? Did you feel different? I don't think about heaven or the afterlife. I don't believe in them. I'm selfish. I want to see my grandfather again one more time. Heaven doesn't comfort me. It just reminds me how little time we have on here. Nothing is guaranteed. At some point, some way, I'll never see somebody ever again. There's nothing I can do about it. Every memory I have will remind me of that. Can I just dwell in the memories? Sure it gives me a brief moment of happiness, but the sadness will soon follow. I just know I'm always going to feel this way whenever I think about my grandfather in the future. He lived a relatively long life, but he suffered through the end of it. He could barely walk. He was just well on his way. I should have known. I should've taken it into consideration. But I figured I'd see him one more time. I didn't think he would die for at least another few years. However, I was simply ignorant of it all. No matter how realistic you are, you're always still a bit naive. And I guess I am with my family. I always think they'll be there, but at some point they won't. In this case, this is it. I'll never see my grandfather, I'll never talk to him. This is just it. Get over it, right? I wish I could, but I can't. Hopefully, I will eventually, but for now I'm just gonna be like this for awhile. I don't want to be, but it's just how I feel. I can't help it. I'm sure most people understand that and I hope they take all this into serious consideration. I don't feel good. I don't feel good at all. No matter what, I don't. And I just have to get it out. I have to try to get this out of my system in every way I can. That is all I can do right now and, unfortunately, anyone who reads this will have to bear with it. I'm sure I'll be back to my normal self eventually, but for now this is me. I'll try to put a smile on my face, I'll try to occupy myself in other ways. But, it's going to be hard. There's no denying that. And for now, this is what I'll leave you with. When I do feel better, I'll let you know. I will. I know I will. This feeling won't last forever, but it exists now. I'm just trying to find anyway to get it out.

For those who want to know what happened in more detail:

My grandpa died on Wednesday. For the past year, he's been living in Whiting, NJ where there's a old folks community. He had his own house and stuff, but it was in a neighborhood with a bunch of old people. My mom and little sister would usually go there every Friday or Saturday to bring him groceries and take care of him or hang out with him. In the beginning, when I could, I'd tag along but they'd stay there so late and all he'd do was just sit there and drink til he got drunk that I just didn't like being there. For the whole summer, my mom and little sis would go see him on the weekend and I'd never go. Yesterday afternoon, my mom asked me if I wanted to go and I declined as usual. An hour or so later, I got a phone call from my mother but she wanted to speak to my stepdad. I gave him the phone outside, he shortly came inside in a panic and soon went over to Whiting where she was. I had no idea what happened and he didn't indicate anything so all I thought was maybe she got in a car accident. Two hours later, my older sister calls me and told me that grandpa died. He was found sitting on the toilet with his head leaning on the sink. He died peacefully. My mom and little sister came home a few hours later and they were both crying. My mom was able to keep her composure quite a bit, but my 9 year old sister was hysterical. Luckily, she didn't have to see him like he was and my mom told her that she found him on his bed. But it was just very painful. I felt especially bad because I hadn't seen him all summer. The last time I saw him was in March during Spring Break. I planned on seeing him at least once before I went back to school, now I regret procrastinating this whole time. But when my relatives came over after going coffin shopping with my mom, they were all talking about the last things he gave them before he passed. That's when I realized that the Guitar Hero II that I was playing on Wednesday all day was the last gift he gave to me. I don't know if I'll be able to play it ever again.

I'll miss him. I wish I could've said goodbye properly, but I won't dwell in that. That's not my fault. It'll just be hard to get over all this.

This year in music has been filled with disappointments and pleasant surprises so far.  I can only hope that it continues to surprise.  But the latest album to come out that has really caught my attention is the just released album by Yo La Tengo.  It's fantastic.  I thought Bob Dylan's "Modern Times" was by far the best record I've heard this year (I know, it's a critical favorite too, but goddamn it is amazing).  But YLT's new album "I am not afraid of you and I will beat your ass" lives up to its title.  The very first track on the record is near-11 minutes of pure bliss.  An unrelenting and killer rhythm complemented by Ira Kaplan's ferocious guitar work.  The thing about that is their last two albums were more atmospheric and hardly had much guitar at all and Ira Kaplan is an excellent and innovative guitarist.  Well, he comes back with a vengeance on the very first track and doesn't let go until 11 minutes later when the even better, shorter, poppier "Beanbag Chair" plays.  YLT is not afraid to make a complete 180 with their sound and they do it perfect here.  After that, everything seems to flow together with a band that for awhile, seemed as if they were running out of ideas.  Now it seems like they've been reborn and rocking out harder than ever before.  Some of the songs are a challenge to listen to (at least 3 songs on here are over 8 minutes in length), but each song is a rewarding listen.  It's a relief to have such a great album like this released this year especially since Mars Volta and Outkast's new albums are both disappointing.  I applaud both for going into different directions with their experimentations, but not all experiments work.  Mars Volta are too wild, they can't be pinned down.  They try so many things and sometimes it works and other times it is just a mess.  Yo La Tengo aren't afraid to experiment either, but they know how to experiment without going off track and losing focus on what they're trying to make.  Too much of something is never good and the more you experiment the more sidetracked you get with different sounds and styles.  You have to keep certain focus, have a focal point in each song.  That's why Pink Floyd's experimental albums such as "Animals" worked so well.  They never lost focus, and it just seems as if Mars Volta can't maintain focus on one sound.  Some people might enjoy that, but there's a different between something that's challenging to listen to and something you can't even follow.  So, while I applaud Mars Volta for their uncomprising experiment and their hard-as-balls work ethic, I just can't seem to enjoy what they're making.  And, to me, that's at least the most important thing.   Who knows, I only listened to the album once.  I'll give it another chance.

Well, as I'm certainly in no mood to go anywhere after that horrific loss Penn State had against Notre Dame, I decided to take the time to write about something that I wanted to talk about musically.

Maybe the fact that today's music scene is particularly lacking, but here's what I've got to say...I miss blink-182. 

What?

Yeah, that's right.  I miss good ol' blink-182.  A band I enjoyed briefly during my intermediate school years.  However, I listened to Korn and Limp Bizkit back then too and you don't hear me missing them.  But, here's the thing:  I recently listened to "Enema of the State" for shits and giggles, and it still a damn catchy album.  No filler, 12 catchy songs clocking in at about 30 minutes.  It doesn't have the guttural punch of Rancid at their best or emotional depth like Green Day at their best, it's just pure fun.  Catchy songwriting without getting too annoying.  Even Tom DeLonge's voice isn't too annoying as it now has become in his new Angels & Airwaves band.  Yeah, I never liked his voice to begin with, but for some reason it works with blink-182's snotty, adolescent sound.  I find, or have found Mark's voice to be a little more pleasant and it's a departure from a typical punk rock singer.  He doesn't whine.  I guess that's why I liked him.  Especially when you got bands today such as Taking Back Sunday and Fall Out Boy who have singers with incredibly annoying voices.  It's irritating. 

Out of the late 90s-early 00s pop-punk bands, blink-182 were the best and the most successful.  They were catchier than the Offspring too, who relied too much on anthemic songs rather than tightning up their structure.  Blink-182, however, by the third album had really tightened up their sound and the way they did that was with Travis Barker.  This guy is a great drummer and he is what makes (or made) blink-182 a credible band.  Looking behind their success during the TRL era, you see a band who took the immaturity and snottiness of punk rock (a la the Descendents and NOFX) and turned into incredibly successful, radio-friendly, and above-all catchy songs.  Their fourth album was a bit half-and-half and that was when I started losing interest in them.  I guess it's hard to maintain a certain level of immaturity (although NOFX did it for years...and now THEY'RE starting to become serious).  There are some lesser successful pop-punk bands during this time that were just as good as blink-182.  Guttermouth, Vandals, Lagwagon are all great bands in their own way, and I'm not trying to take anything away from them.  But blink-182's "Enema of the State" is probably the most fun album out of them all.  Sum 41 tries, but their album "All Killer, No Filler" is false advertising.  It's almost all filler, trust me.  They seemed to be trying to ride on the coattails of blink-182 too much and they just weren't as catchy.  Blink-182's songwriting wasn't complex in the least, but it didn't need to be.  If you can make short, poppy, catchy songs that rarely get old (listen to "What's My Age Again?"  one more time...it hasn't gotten old).

I only made this entry because people think back at blink-182 and they dismiss them for some reason.  Well, listen to the shit that's on the radio now.  Blink-182 were miles better than them.  Where's the fun, where's the explicit, potty-mouth lyrics?  Give me a break.  Better yet, do any of today's bands have a drummer that is as talented as Travis?  No.  So fuck off.

Who doesn't love money?  We're all in different situations when it comes to the $$ and those who are rich spend thousands of dollars at ease and others spend money at the thrift store.  When you're in a multi-billion dollar business, anything that can be potentially damaging...eh...slide it under the door.

But what about if the damage can't fit under the door?  What if you're the commissioner of MLB? 

Is everybody in sports taking steroids?  Olympic atheletes, baseball players, cyclists?  Dear god, man.  Baseball players have been doing it for decades, I believe every word of Jose Canseco's book even if he is a slimy douchebag.  So what about money?  Well, MLB is a multi-billion dollar business, correct?  If you're Bud Selig in the mid-90s and the media has yet to find out the Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa are shooting up in the locker room...but you know all about it...why crack down on it?  If it is making you money, why stop it?  And if the truth comes out and could damage your business.  So, it only makes sense why Bud Selig wouldn't say anything or crack down on steroids from a financial standpoint.  However, if baseball players are taking the same illegal drugs as WWE wrestlers, there is a problem.  It's amazing, ain't it?  How somebody like Barry Bonds's best friend would risk going to jail for years for not ratting him out.  Everybody knows Barry Bonds took steroids, it's all a matter of how it's going to come out in front of a grand jury.  So why not tell the truth?  Why put yourself through the risk?  On the flipside, if you're Barry Bonds and you know what the truth is...are you willing to let your friend go to jail for not telling the truth?  Yeah, what a great role model this guy is. 

I feel like I'm talking about too many things at once, but my feeling is that the MLB is kind of like a mafia of some sort.  If you squeal, you get your legs broken.  There are a ton of illegal things, I bet, that goes on in the MLB and if somebody leaks it out they'll have a much tougher time than Russel Crowe's character did in 'The Insider.'  You probably didn't see that movie, but basically what happens is that Russel Crowe works at a tobacco company when he suddenly gets fired.  The TV Show '60 Minutes' wants to do a story about this tobacco company that could damage them.  Russel Crowe's character wants to speak, but the tobacco company terrorizes his family to get him to stop.  Yeah.  Exactly.  Eerie, is it not?  It's funny how we look at a business like organized crime in disdain, but come on...other businesses are just as bad and why?  Because of the money.  Money makes the world go 'round, doesn't it?  So why be honest?  You can be an honest man and earn a million dollars, but once you make that first million...why stop there?  Then, you do anything you can to make more money even if it means having to lie, cheat, and steal.  That's how I view the MLB.  In simple words:  MLB makes billions of dollars, steroid-infested players help make that revenue, MLB therefore keeps mouth shut.  Suddenly, the truth (steroids) comes out in the media, MLB is shuffling to get people not to talk, one of the biggest stars (Barry Bonds) is a prime suspect of being a user and his best friend is willing not to testify even if it means going to jail.  Wow.

My infatuation with the band Yeah Yeah Yeahs and their lead singer Karen O has grown over the past few years.  At first I dismissed them as merely being a part of the fad of garage rock without even hearing them.  However, "Fever to Tell" turns out to be the album I listened to the most throughout my senior year.  It helps that it's raw, fast, and less than 40 minutes long.  What fascinated me about the album was how Karen O turned from an all-out raunchy, sex-filled girl into a more vulnerable, human, introspective woman.  While she never loses her swagger, she essentially pours her heart out in the album and it becomes something more than a stylistic, fast-paced rock album.  The last three songs off "Fever to Tell" is what makes the album complete.  While some may not like the fact that the slower, ballad-like songs are at the end, I think that's the genius of it.  It doesn't work on all albums, but an album like this it does.  I think the rawness of the first 6-7 songs wouldn't feel so powerful if they were split up by slower ballads.  I think it's better to kind of split the album into two.  

YYY's latest album "Show Your Bones" picks off where the end of "Fever to Tell" left off.  It's more emotional and while I was a little taken aback by how lackluster in energy it was compared to their first album, I've grown to love the album the more I listen to it.  It's a grower.  And it just might have proven to me that Karen O is one of the greatest frontwomen in the history of rock n roll.  We'll see, of course.  It's pretty hard to beat Debbie Harry.  Debbie Harry was sexy and had a great voice, Pat Benatar had a lot of attitude and was also sexy.  Karen O has a great voice, attitude, she's definitely more sexual than them, and she also has the ability to swing from raunchiness to vulnerability and never making it sound forced or out-of-place.  She's also hot as hell.  While her beauty may not stand out when you see her at first, it's when you see her on stage.  She certainly has the greatest stage presence out of any other woman I've ever seen.  This is not to put her bandmates in the shadows.  But, let's face it, Yeah Yeah Yeahs main focus is Karen O.  She could never be replaced.  The other two band members are great at what they do and they definitely complement Karen very well.  Nevertheless,  this band has the ability to make more great albums and hopefully they could more seamlessly capture their rawness and softness in the future.  It would seem more like a retreat if they went back to their earlier sound.  The only step they can make now is to expand on their previous two records.  As for Karen O, she's unpredictable.  She has the ability to surprise and hypnotize.  I have a feeling that this band, or at least Karen O will stick around for quite awhile.

What emo is today and what Mineral started over 10 years ago are two totally different things.  While Mineral didn't start the movement of emo, they definitely best exemplify what it's supposed to be all about...emotion.

You see, Mineral did it right.  Many other bands did it right, but Mineral did it best.  They created an atmosphere that allowed the lyrics to not sound cheesy and to make it sound powerful.  Their music built up to a climax like our emotions do.  Whining isn't an emotion.  Sadness and happiness don't just happen, they build.  And not many bands over the past 20 years put that to music better than Mineral.  This is why I have a problem with bands like Taking Back Sunday.  They don't bring out any true emotion.  There's just a bunch of screaming and nonsense.  This genre of music has become so formulaic and repetitive that many people forget what it was all about in the first place...emotion.  All music has emotion, but bands like Mineral and Sunny Day Real Estate, and early Death Cab For Cutie all brought out emotion in an atmospheric way.  It's the sound, the intensity, the climax, the lyrics that weren't just about heartache but about feelings.  But about feelings of happiness and sadness themselves.  Sure you can sing about love lost, unrequited love, broken heart...but you don't have to whine about it.  Nobody likes a crybaby.  Don't cry about love lost, reflect on it.  Think about it.  That's what Mineral did.  I wish more people would see it that way and realize that that's what "emo" is truly about.  It's not about the clothes, your look...a sad face doesn't mean you're depressed.  There's more to emotion than that, don't forget it.  And goddamnit, stop being so miserable.  It is possible to write about happiness too.

So I'm listening to London Calling by the Clash...for the 50th time...and yes.

It is without a doubt, still, the greatest album I've ever heard.  Keep in mind, I've listened to Revolver, Pet Sounds, Zeppelin's IV, all that shit man.  I've heard all the classics.  London Calling goes from one style to the other effortlessly.  From rock to reggae to rockabilly to...anything you can think of....they cover it all in this record.  If you don't like any of these songs, there is something wrong with you.  It doesn't matter what you're a fan of, there is no denying the power of Joe Strummer's voice.  It's not just the songwriting, the production is excellent too.  The sound is full, every square inch covered with music.  The sequence is perfect even with sticking the love song (or anti-love song) at the end.  It's ingenius.  Some bands have filler tracks on albums that only have about 10 or 11 songs, but London Calling has 18 brilliant tracks.  It is perfection.  It is the culmination of what is great about music and if you can't like, appreciate, or understand that, then there is something wrong with you.  This album is important.  It influenced so many with its message, its music, its diversity, its willingness to try anything.  On top of all that, there are just great songs on here.  The reason why the reggae/dub songs work so well with the straight-ahead rock or punk songs is because they're all...genuinely great songs.  They're not just trying it for the hell of it, they've perfected every style they've tried.  They were virtuosos.  And they released the amazing failure of Sandinista! a year later.  How?  That's ridiculous.  How do you top a 2 LP album?  A 3 LP album.  Is it better than London Calling?  No way.  But its ambition, the willingness to take their music to the next step, to try anything makes Sandinista! so great and underappreciated.  It's such a sprawling, long album.  But after repeated listenings, it's a rewarding record.

Maybe releasing 4 great albums in a row containing over 100 songs wasn't such a great idea as far as durability goes.  They could've just released a bunch of 8-10 song albums year after year and last much longer.  But that would be missing the point, I guess.  Listen to the album.  If you hate it, you're stupid.    Simple as that.
